meanings.definition: To draw into the mouth by contracting the muscles of the lips and mouth to make a partial vacuum.
meanings.sent1: The baby sucked on her pacifier.
meanings.sent2: She sucked the straw to drink her juice.
meanings.sent3: The vacuum cleaner sucked up all the dirt from the carpet.
meanings.sent4: The black hole sucked in everything around it.
meanings.sent5: The tornado sucked up debris and leaves in its path.

meanings.definition: To be very bad or unpleasant.
meanings.sent1: The movie sucked, and I want my money back.
meanings.sent2: The food at that restaurant sucked last time.
meanings.sent3: The rainy weather really sucked the fun out of our picnic.
meanings.sent4: The broken air conditioner sucked the cool air out of the room.
meanings.sent5: The long wait at the doctor's office sucked all my patience away.

meanings.definition: To be inferior or in need of improvement.
meanings.sent1: His drawing skills sucked compared to his sister's.
meanings.sent2: The old computer really sucked at running new software.
meanings.sent3: The team's performance sucked, but they promised to do better next time.
meanings.sent4: Her excuse for being late sucked the creativity out of the room.
meanings.sent5: The cheap glue sucked at holding the pieces together.
